---
created: "2026-01-20T03:24:26Z"
updated: "2026-01-20T03:24:26Z"
title: "Coding Agents are Addictive"
description: "Many lessons learned"
tags: ["ai", "programming", "Claude", "Simon Willison", "Armin Ronacher"]
---

Despite having used LLMs since before they could produce reasonable English paragraphs, and despite reading [Simon Willison](https://simonwillison.net/) and [Armin Ronacher](https://lucumr.pocoo.org/) wax rhapsodic about what they've been able to accomplish the AI agents, I've been stuck in the occasionally-copy-from-chat routine.

Then [Steve Yegge introduced beads](https://steve-yegge.medium.com/introducing-beads-a-coding-agent-memory-system-637d7d92514a) which seemed interesting until it [turned out to be a bit of a nightmare](https://lucumr.pocoo.org/2026/1/18/agent-psychosis/). But there was something about how he tied agent work to the way humans work that made it click for me and so a little over a week ago I decided to install [Claude Code](https://code.claude.com/docs/en/overview).

But what to try it on? Let's start with something I've been procrastinating on: [drawing process trees for `ds`](https://github.com/metaist/ds/issues/93). It did a bunch of research, wrote some code, and then [24 minutes later](/static/assets/transcripts/2026-01-11-1204-ds.html#entry-90f5a7ca-7c1d-48cd-8dea-52b26fef9213) it was done.

Ok, I think, I've had some success with code reviews. [Let's try that](/static/assets/transcripts/2026-01-11-1204-ds.html#entry-3da2afa2-3337-46d3-874b-e01cd974d171). And then [that was done](/static/assets/transcripts/2026-01-11-1204-ds.html#entry-5a92d123-57e7-442a-b815-c84c8e857115).

Overall here's how [fixing the entire backlog of `ds` went](/static/assets/transcripts/2026-01-11-1204-ds.html). (Towards the end I used this session to also create docs for `cosmofy`.)

<div style="font-family:ui-monospace,'Cascadia Code',Consolas,monospace;font-size:11px;background:#16213e;border-radius:6px;padding:8px 12px;max-width:1897px;">
  <div style="color:#808080;margin-bottom:6px;display:flex;gap:12px;flex-wrap:wrap;">

    <span title="Time spent by the AI generating responses and running tools"><span style="display:inline-block;width:10px;height:10px;background:#8abeb7;border-radius:2px;margin-right:3px;vertical-align:middle;"></span><strong style="color:#e5e5e7;">Agent</strong> 1838 msgs 4h 29m 42%</span>
    <span title="Gaps longer than 20 minutes where user was away"><span style="display:inline-block;width:10px;height:10px;background:#0a0a10;border-radius:2px;margin-right:3px;vertical-align:middle;"></span><strong style="color:#e5e5e7;">Idle</strong> 44h 24m</span>

And then I started building [`cosmo-python`](https://github.com/metaist/cosmo-python/) in Claude Code, but switched to [`pi-coding-agent`](https://shittycodingagent.ai/). Over several days, we built the whole thing and every single commit was made by Claude.

Ok, so then I wanted to write this post with links to transcripts. `pi` has a native `/share` that generates a secret gist which is cool, but I wanted some more visualization of who was doing what.

And that [burned a whole day](/static/assets/transcripts/2026-01-19-1507-pi2html.html).

---

## Reflections

Working with coding agents is extremely addictive. The agent works quickly, but it requires some amount of your attention. How _much_ attention, though? Things get pretty thorny quickly.

<blockquote class="twitter-tweet"><p lang="en" dir="ltr">One reason vibe coding is so addictive is that you are always *almost* there but not 100% there. The agent implements an amazing feature and got maybe 10% of the thing wrong, and you are like &quot;hey I can fix this if i just prompt it for 5 more mins&quot;<br><br>And that was 5 hrs ago</p>&mdash; Yoko (@stuffyokodraws) <a href="https://twitter.com/stuffyokodraws/status/2013373307291340870?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw">January 19, 2026</a></blockquote> <script async src="https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

1. **Objective criteria let you delegate.** If the agent needs to wait for you to figure out if things are working, you're still working on the problem and you haven't delegated it. Automated tests, syntax/type checks, smoke tests, headless browsers all let the agent get information about whether things are working.

2. **Iterate on specs first.** This is true for humans too. Don't let the agent build the first rev because it's easy. You'll end up iterating all day. Do lots of throwaway experiments to figure out what the criteria should be instead of doing a huge rewrite every time you want a new feature.

3. **Code reviews work.** When I did extensive code reviews for `cosmo-python`, it ended up making the tools simpler for both humans and agents to understand.

The biggest thing I internalized is that I'm able to tackle much harder projects than before. There's still work to be done in terms of producing "[code you have proven to work](https://simonwillison.net/2025/Dec/18/code-proven-to-work/)". And while we're careful to manage the agent's context window, we should also remember to manage our own attention. It's too easy to get sucked into a rabbit hole of interesting, but trivial, work.
